headline: Toy makers rush into ‘blind box’ trend for holidays following Labubu craze
summary: NEW YORK (Reuters) -While U.S. consumers keep searching for an authentic Pop Mart Labubu, rivals are introducing their own cheaper, easier-to-find "blind box" products for the key holiday shopping season to capitalize on the craze sparked by the fuzzy mini monsters.  Hot gift lists from retailers like ​Walmart feature a new crop of blind box figurines and trading cards, and U.S. companies including Hasbro and Mattel are selling versions of toys like Furby and Barbie in ‌mystery packaging, incorporating the trend.  A blind box toy – like Spin Master's popular CrystaLynx dragons – generally has packaging that hides the specific product inside so shoppers keep buying until they find the one they want or collect the whole ‌series.

content.title: Toy makers rush into ‘blind box’ trend for holidays following Labubu craze
content.summary: NEW YORK (Reuters) -While U.S. consumers keep searching for an authentic Pop Mart Labubu, rivals are introducing their own cheaper, easier-to-find "blind box" products for the key holiday shopping season to capitalize on the craze sparked by the fuzzy mini monsters.  Hot gift lists from retailers like ​Walmart feature a new crop of blind box figurines and trading cards, and U.S. companies including Hasbro and Mattel are selling versions of toys like Furby and Barbie in ‌mystery packaging, incorporating the trend.  A blind box toy – like Spin Master's popular CrystaLynx dragons – generally has packaging that hides the specific product inside so shoppers keep buying until they find the one they want or collect the whole ‌series.

headline: Rattled Bulls Look to Strong Earnings Outlooks as Market Wobbles
summary: The labor market still looks shaky, going by private data and a spate of layoffs.  Federal Reserve officials are signaling they might not cut again this year as the threat to inflation from tariffs persists.  Fresh off profit growth of 15% in the third quarter, profit guidance momentum, a measure of the share of S&P 500 members that lifted their earnings outlooks compared to those that maintained or lowered views, has climbed to the highest level since 2021, according to data compiled by Bloomberg Intelligence.

content.title: Rattled Bulls Look to Strong Earnings Outlooks as Market Wobbles
content.summary: The labor market still looks shaky, going by private data and a spate of layoffs.  Federal Reserve officials are signaling they might not cut again this year as the threat to inflation from tariffs persists.  Fresh off profit growth of 15% in the third quarter, profit guidance momentum, a measure of the share of S&P 500 members that lifted their earnings outlooks compared to those that maintained or lowered views, has climbed to the highest level since 2021, according to data compiled by Bloomberg Intelligence.

headline: Walmart CEO Doug McMillon to retire in January and US operations chief John Furner will take over
summary: Walmart CEO Doug McMillon, who turned the nation's largest retailer into a tech-powered giant since taking over in 2014, will retire in January. John Furner, a long time insider and head of Walmart's U.S. operations, will take over, the company said Friday. McMillon's retirement is effective Jan. 31, 2026.

headline: Walmart Announces John Furner as President and Chief Executive Officer
summary: BENTONVILLE, Ark., November 14, 2025--Walmart Inc. (NYSE: WMT) today announced that its Board of Directors has elected John Furner, 51, to succeed Doug McMillon, 59, as President and Chief Executive Officer of Walmart Inc., effective February 1, 2026. Furner was also elected to the company’s Board of Directors, effective immediately. McMillon will retire on January 31, 2026, but remain on the Board of Directors until the next annual shareholders’ meeting and help ensure a smooth transition.

content.title: Walmart Announces John Furner as President and Chief Executive Officer
content.summary: BENTONVILLE, Ark., November 14, 2025--Walmart Inc. (NYSE: WMT) today announced that its Board of Directors has elected John Furner, 51, to succeed Doug McMillon, 59, as President and Chief Executive Officer of Walmart Inc., effective February 1, 2026. Furner was also elected to the company’s Board of Directors, effective immediately. McMillon will retire on January 31, 2026, but remain on the Board of Directors until the next annual shareholders’ meeting and help ensure a smooth transition.

thumbnail.caption: Walmart Announces John Furner as President and Chief Executive Officer - John Furner (left) will succeed Doug McMillon (right) as President and Chief Executive Officer of Walmart Inc., effective February 1, 2026. McMillon will retire on January 31, 2026, but remain on the Board of Directors until the next annual shareholders’ meeting and help ensure a smooth transition.

headline: Stocks fall on Fed fears, Walmart CEO, Trump tariffs: 3 Things
summary: US stock futures (ES=F, NQ=F, YM=F) are falling in Friday's premarket as Wall Street digests the federal spending bill that Trump signed to reopen the government and worries that Federal Reserve officials may not be in full agreement to cut interest rates in December. Walmart (WMT) CEO Doug McMillon announced his plans to retire at the end of January 2026, to be succeeded in his chief executive role by Walmart US CEO John Furner. President Trump is reportedly looking to make tariff exemptions in an attempt to ease food prices and Americans' affordability anxieties, according to the Wall Street Journal. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

content.title: Stocks fall on Fed fears, Walmart CEO, Trump tariffs: 3 Things
content.description:
US stock futures (ES=F, NQ=F, YM=F) are falling in Friday's premarket as Wall Street digests the federal spending bill that Trump signed to reopen the government and worries that Federal Reserve officials may not be in full agreement to cut interest rates in December.

Walmart (WMT) CEO Doug McMillon announced his plans to retire at the end of January 2026, to be succeeded in his chief executive role by Walmart US CEO John Furner.

President Trump is reportedly looking to make tariff exemptions in an attempt to ease food prices and Americans' affordability anxieties, according to the Wall Street Journal.

To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

Walmart (WMT) CEO Doug McMillon announced his plans to retire at the end of January 2026, to be succeeded in his chief executive role by Walmart US CEO John Furner. President Trump is reportedly looking to make tariff exemptions in an attempt to ease food prices and Americans' affordability anxieties, according to the Wall Street Journal. headline: Meet the New CEO of Walmart
summary: BUSINESS   John Furner, the Walmart lifer who was named Doug McMillon’s successor as chief executive, has been leading the U.S. arm of the retail behemoth for several years. It was a role that he stepped into just a few months before the Covid-19 pandemic began.

content.title: Meet the New CEO of Walmart
content.summary: BUSINESS   John Furner, the Walmart lifer who was named Doug McMillon’s successor as chief executive, has been leading the U.S. arm of the retail behemoth for several years. It was a role that he stepped into just a few months before the Covid-19 pandemic began.

headline: Walmart CEO Doug McMillon to Step Down
summary: Walmart  said Friday that Chief Executive  Doug McMillon  would step down after over a decade in the role, a change at the top of the country’s largest retailer and private employer as it navigates a complex consumer and government landscape.  John Furner,  current chief executive of Walmart U.S., will succeed McMillon as CEO after the end of the company’s fiscal year Feb. 1, the company said.  The 51-year-old Furner has served as president and CEO of Walmart U.S. since 2019, overseeing the company’s largest operating segment and more than 4,600 stores.

content.title: Walmart CEO Doug McMillon to Step Down
content.summary: Walmart  said Friday that Chief Executive  Doug McMillon  would step down after over a decade in the role, a change at the top of the country’s largest retailer and private employer as it navigates a complex consumer and government landscape.  John Furner,  current chief executive of Walmart U.S., will succeed McMillon as CEO after the end of the company’s fiscal year Feb. 1, the company said.  The 51-year-old Furner has served as president and CEO of Walmart U.S. since 2019, overseeing the company’s largest operating segment and more than 4,600 stores.

headline: Walmart CEO McMillon to Retire in February, US Head Will Take Over
summary: Walmart's CEO Doug McMillon is stepping down marking the end of an era for the world's largest retailer. McMillon, who rose from hourly worker to chief executive, will hand the reins over to the company's US head John Furner. Bloomberg's Emily Cohn leads Bloomberg's consumer team and she joined Bloomberg Open Interest with details on the leadership shake-up.

Bloomberg's Emily Cohn leads Bloomberg's consumer team and she joined Bloomberg Open Interest with details on the leadership shake-up.

headline: These Stocks Are Moving the Most Today: Tesla, Applied Materials, Nvidia, Walmart, Strategy, Warner Bros., and More
summary: Stock futures were falling on Friday, as investors continued to worry about lofty valuations for tech companies.  The chip equipment maker reported better-than-expected earnings and revenue after Thursday’s close, and also forecast solid results for the current quarter, which ends in January.  Investors may have been looking for stronger results, given the stock’s recent rally.

headline: Walmart Stock Drops. CEO Doug McMillon Is Retiring.
summary: Walmart  stock dropped in premarket trading Friday after the world’s largest retailer announced longtime CEO Doug McMillon was retiring next year.  John Furner, currently serving as CEO of Walmart U.S., will succeed McMillon, effective Feb. 1, Walmart said.  McMillon will officially retire Jan. 31, but will remain on Walmart’s board of directors until the company’s next annual shareholder meeting to ensure a smooth transition, the company said.

headline: Walmart CEO Doug McMillon announces his surprise retirement at age 59
summary: Walmart CEO Doug McMillon, who turned America's largest retailer into a tech-powered giant and spearheaded a period of robust sales growth since becoming chief executive in 2014, plans to retire early next year, the company said Friday in a surprise announcement.  John Furner, 51, the head of Walmart's U.S. operations, will take over on Feb. 1, the day after McMillon's retirement becomes effective, the company said.  Although McMillon is set to spend a year advising his successor, Walmart shares fell 3% immediately in premarket trading after the news of the unexpected leadership change.

content.title: Walmart CEO Doug McMillon announces his surprise retirement at age 59
content.summary: Walmart CEO Doug McMillon, who turned America's largest retailer into a tech-powered giant and spearheaded a period of robust sales growth since becoming chief executive in 2014, plans to retire early next year, the company said Friday in a surprise announcement.  John Furner, 51, the head of Walmart's U.S. operations, will take over on Feb. 1, the day after McMillon's retirement becomes effective, the company said.  Although McMillon is set to spend a year advising his successor, Walmart shares fell 3% immediately in premarket trading after the news of the unexpected leadership change.

headline: Walmart’s Doug McMillon to Step Down as CEO After Over a Decade
summary: Walmart  said Friday that Chief Executive  Doug McMillon  would step down after over a decade in the role, a change at the top of the country’s largest retailer and private employer as it navigates a complex consumer and government landscape.  John Furner,  current chief executive of Walmart U.S., will succeed McMillon as CEO after the end of the company’s fiscal year Feb. 1, the company said.  The 51-year-old Furner has served as president and CEO of Walmart U.S. since 2019, overseeing the company’s largest operating segment and more than 4,600 stores.

content.title: Walmart’s Doug McMillon to Step Down as CEO After Over a Decade
content.summary: Walmart  said Friday that Chief Executive  Doug McMillon  would step down after over a decade in the role, a change at the top of the country’s largest retailer and private employer as it navigates a complex consumer and government landscape.  John Furner,  current chief executive of Walmart U.S., will succeed McMillon as CEO after the end of the company’s fiscal year Feb. 1, the company said.  The 51-year-old Furner has served as president and CEO of Walmart U.S. since 2019, overseeing the company’s largest operating segment and more than 4,600 stores.

headline: Walmart Stock Drops as CEO Doug McMillon Announces Retirement. It’s the End of an Era.
summary: Walmart  stock dropped Friday after the world’s largest retailer announced longtime CEO Doug McMillon was retiring next year.  John Furner, 51, currently serving as CEO of Walmart U.S., will succeed McMillon, 59, effective Feb. 1, Walmart said.  McMillon will officially retire Jan. 31, but will remain on Walmart’s board of directors until the company’s next annual shareholder meeting to ensure a smooth transition, the company said.

content.title: Walmart Stock Drops as CEO Doug McMillon Announces Retirement. It’s the End of an Era.

John Furner, 51, currently serving as CEO of Walmart U.S., will succeed McMillon, 59, effective Feb. 1, Walmart said.  McMillon will officially retire Jan. 31, but will remain on Walmart’s board of directors until the company’s next annual shareholder meeting to ensure a smooth transition, the company said.

headline: Who Is John Furner? Meet the Walmart Insider Named New CEO
summary: John Furner,  the  Walmart  lifer who was named  Doug McMillon’s  successor as chief executive, has been leading the U.S. arm of the retail behemoth for several years, a role he stepped into just months before the Covid-19 pandemic began.  Furner’s Walmart roots are deep.  In the late 1980s, when Furner was a teenager, his mother, Lana, was diagnosed with breast cancer.

headline: Walmart shares fall as CEO announces exit
summary:
STORY: Walmart is gearing up for a major shake-up at the helm of the retail giant.

Longtime CEO Doug McMillon says he’ll retire next year, stepping down after more than a decade leading the company.

McMillon oversaw the world’s largest retailer's transformation into a tech-driven powerhouse.

He also helped triple Walmart’s market value to more than 800 billion dollars, leaning hard into e-commerce and new technologies.

Walmart shares fell in early trading, as some investors worried the move came a bit earlier than expected.

The company also announced his successor, John Furner, who is the current head of Walmart U.S.

Furner is a company veteran with three decades inside the business.

He started as an hourly associate at Walmart in 1993, much like McMillon did back in 1984.

Walmart says the shift is part of a long-planned transition, and McMillon will continue as an adviser through Jan. 31, 2027.

The leadership change comes as the broader retail sector faces tariff pressures, an uneven economy, and choppy consumer spending, with several major chains like Target and Kohl's naming new CEOs this year.

Walmart is set to report quarterly results next week.

headline: Walmart CEO's exit is a surprise, investment manager says
summary:
STORY: Walmart CEO Doug McMillon will retire next year after more than a decade at the helm, capping a period when he reshaped the big-box retailer into a technology-driven powerhouse.

McMillon, will be replaced by U.S. division chief CEO John Furner, a retail veteran with three decades at the company, Walmart said.

Glockner said many investors expected McMillon to stay on longer, noting he had previously signaled he had “at least three years left,” in 2023.

She added that “John Furner is possibly the most logical successor,” and that Walmart’s strategy should remain steady even as “the consumer is slowing.”

content.title: Walmart CEO's exit is a surprise, investment manager says
content.summary:
STORY: Walmart CEO Doug McMillon will retire next year after more than a decade at the helm, capping a period when he reshaped the big-box retailer into a technology-driven powerhouse.

McMillon, will be replaced by U.S. division chief CEO John Furner, a retail veteran with three decades at the company, Walmart said.

Glockner said many investors expected McMillon to stay on longer, noting he had previously signaled he had “at least three years left,” in 2023.

She added that “John Furner is possibly the most logical successor,” and that Walmart’s strategy should remain steady even as “the consumer is slowing.”
